required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Pudendal Nerve Block in Vaginal Surgery
clinical_study.official_title: The Effect of Pudendal Nerve Block Analgesia on Postoperative Pain Control in Patients Undergoing Vaginal Surgery: A Randomized Double-blind Placebo-controlled Trial

brief_summary.textblock: The objective of this this randomized controlled study is to determine whether a pudendal nerve block at the time of vaginal surgery is associated with improved postoperative pain control and decrease opioid consumption compared to a sham pudendal nerve block in patients undergoing vaginal surgery.

study_design_info.masking: Quadruple (Participant, Care Provider, Investigator, Outcomes Assessor)

primary_outcome.measure: Visual Analog Scores at 7am after surgery
primary_outcome.description: Visual analog score: 0 (No pain) - 10 (The worst imaginable pain)

secondary_outcome.measure: Visual analog scores at discharge from post-anesthesia care unit
secondary_outcome.time_frame: At the time of discharge from post-anesthesia care unit, on average 1-3 hours
secondary_outcome.description: Visual analog score: 0 (No pain) - 10 (The worst imaginable pain)
Numeric rating pain scale: 0 (No pain) - 10 (The worst imaginable pain)

secondary_outcome.measure: Quality of Recovery scores on post op day 1 (7AM)
secondary_outcome.description: Quality of Recovery score: Part A 18 (very poor) - 90 (excellent); Part B 22 (excellent) - 110 (very poor)

secondary_outcome.measure: Satisfaction scores in the morning after surgery (7AM)
secondary_outcome.description: Satisfaction with overall pain control: 0 (Not satisfied at all) - 10 (Extremely satisfied)
Satisfaction with overall pain control: 0 (Not satisfied at all) - 10 (Extremely satisfied)

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Through the time of hospital discharge, on average 15-20 hours
secondary_outcome.description: Length of inpatient hospitalization after surgery

secondary_outcome.measure: Opioid analgesic use in the post-anesthesia care unit
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Through the time of discharge from the post-anesthesia care unit, on average 1-3 hours
secondary_outcome.description: Total dose of opioids administered in the post-anesthesia care unit, in morphine equivalents.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Through the time of hospital discharge, on average 15-20 hours
secondary_outcome.description: Total dose of opioids administered during the first 24 hours after surgery, in morphine equivalents.
Quality of Recovery Score, Part B "Comfort": 8 (none of the time) - 40 (All of the time)

arm_group.description: 9cc of 0.25% Marcaine + 1cc of 40mg/mL triamcinolone. 5cc will be injected transvaginally in the area of the pudendal nerve on each side.
10cc normal saline. 5cc will be injected transvaginally in the area of the pudendal nerve on each side.

intervention.description: Administration of a pudendal block at the conclusion of vaginal surgery.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Consenting, English speaking women between ages 18 and 80 who will undergo vaginal surgery
- Ability to read VAS Scores
- Specific vaginal procedures include, but are not limited to:
Perineoplasty Complete vaginectomy Le Forte colpocleisis Anterior repair, posterior repair, and/or enterocele repair Transvaginal mesh use Transvaginal mesh excision Sacrospinous ligament fixation Uterosacral ligament suspension Vaginal paravaginal defect repair Midurethral sling placement Sphincteroplasty Vaginal hysterectomy, with or without removal of tube(s) and/or ovary(s), with or without repair of enterocele
Exclusion Criteria:
- History of chronic pelvic pain
- Currently taking sedatives
- Liver disease
- Renal disease
- Women who did not consent for the study.
- Intraoperative concern for increased blood loss
- Unable to speak English
- Unable to understand VAS Scores
- Undergoing concomitant abdominal or laparoscopic procedures
- Allergy to bupivacaine or triamcinolone
- Planned abdominal or laparoscopic procedures.
- Patients who are ineligible for non-narcotic pain medications, such as an allergy to acetaminophen or NSAIDs
